title: What will be OPEC's crude oil production for June 2020?
possible_answers: More than 21,000 tb/d but less than 24,000 tb/d
correct_answer: More than 21,000 tb/d but less than 24,000 tb/d
preds: Reconsidered thanks to @K-M-G pointing out Reuters article about June OPEC production. Thanks, K-M-G!
Doubling down now that I see C-paxon's update as well.

We all hate admitting it, but I made 2 mistakes on this question  9.7M bpd reduction is for OPEC+, not OPEC, OPEC's reduction is ~6.0M bpd from May first values.  Secondly, as the table is calculated as a monthly average, the daily output at the end of June, likely above ~24M bpd, is NOT the final monthly total reported. Heavy revision and a reminder to read things carefully. @Soren_G, @thegaul
Going whole hog for one day. What a thrill.
You know when you are playing checkers and get down to just two kings chasing each other around the board? That's how this feels.

Inspired by @Moglj and the most recent numbers from May I am adjusting my numbers https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/oil/061020-opec-delivers-85-compliance-on-oil-output-cuts-in-may-sampp-global-platts-survey https://www.opec.org/opec_web/en/publications/5844.htm

Notes; "OPEC’s 13 members dropped their output to 24.32 million b/d, for a compliance rate of 82% with their prescribed cuts,” S&P Global Platts found in a survey released Wednesday."
from https://www.cnbc.com/2020/06/11/opec-mostly-met-cut-targets-in-may-but-future-compliance-uncertain.html Coupled this with the news at compliance will go to 100% (from June 18 meeting) Assuming 82% is of the 9.7M target we have; 82% of 9.7M = 7.95M
9.7M - 7.95M = 1.75M  24.32M - 1.75M = 22.75M bpd, Alternatively from April production value;  30.4M - 9.7M = 20.7M
Iraq has agreed to better compliance.
Don't know enough about this topic

The OPEC production in April 2020 was 30,412 tb/d. For May, the OPEC production based on secondary sources is 24,320 tb/d. June production is expected to similar to May. OPEC production cut plan compliance is expected to improve further in the month of June pushing the production in 21k-24k tb/d bracket.

given glut of  rude oil on market during April May period, and lack of storage capacity, volume will be reduced until refinery capacity can adjust - even with a rebound in demand supplies will remain high

So far compliance to agreed cuts have been in the low 80% range. With the cuts they were just a shade over 24,000 barrels and looks like the cuts will remain in place. July could see a spike in output
After months of increased production OPEC members finally lowered production from April to May.  From 30k tb/d to 24k tb/d file:///C:/Users/sdog5/Downloads/OPEC_MOMR_June_2020.pdf
May production was 24,000.  Going to lean more on the upper bound, rather than the lower of that range.

The OPEC production in April 2020 was 30,412 tb/d. For May, the OPEC production based on secondary sources is 24,320 tb/d. June production is expected to similar to May. June number will be toss up between the 2 brackets.

With the release of the latest numbers from OPEC I predict June production to be between 24,000 tb/d and 27,000 tb/d. April numbers indicated 29,003 tb/d based on direct communication (no data for Gabon, Iran, or Libya) and 30,412 based on secondary sources. Production effects took place on 01 May and on 12 May Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Kuwait announced that they would voluntarily deepen oil output adjustments from June, by 1 mb/d, 100 tb/d and 80 tb/d, respectively, in an effort to expedite draining a global supply glut and rebalancing the oil market. With a second wave of COVID-19 infections hitting large countries I imagine cuts will remain past June.
OPEC has 1bn bbl excess inventory from March that has to clear, despite expected increase in June/July demand.

From OPEC's World Oil Supply for May. "According to secondary sources, total OPEC-13 preliminary crude oil production averaged 30.41 mb/d in April, 2020"  Anyone who is successful with this prediction, so be working in a different job.

KSA and Kuwait have committed to lowering production to reduce the global oil supply. Even with those commitments, production increased from March 2020 to April 2020 by 1700 tb/d.  file:///C:/Users/sdog5/Downloads/OPEC_MOMR_May_2020.pdf

Reports indicate that in order to stabilize price and decreased demand promised production cuts for June will proceed. March numbers reported above 27,000 tb/d. I forecast the cuts will drop production to between 21,000 and 24,000 tb/d.

Based on projections for crude production for the Americas, primarily the US, for the Q2 and the rest of the year, in trying to protect its market share, the output for OPEC should come down somewhat, but not by more than 2-3 tb/d compared to Feb levels. However, there is a roughly equal chance that the actual production is above or below the 25-26k tb/d level that is most likely
governments are opening up the economy and that means more people moving about and purchasing gas and using airfare.
The OPEC production in April 2020 was 30,412 tb/d. For May, the OPEC production based on secondary sources is 24,320 tb/d. June production is expected to similar to May.
Mexico is continuing to resist further cuts, and several economies in the equation need ready cash to make up for expenditures.

24.77 m/b/d a day so far in may or a 5.91 drop. Supposed to be 9.7 drop or 3.8 more. Compliance by Iraq and Nigeria not good so another about 3.8 if they comply. That would be 20.97. Probably not full compliance so higher.

Current inventories are already overstocked.  Prices are through the floor compared to last year.  Demand is not likely to increase with most people still staying at home as much as possible and air travel heavily restricted.

Global oil demand is going to be larger than ever once economic activity gets back to normal near the end of 2020. It is is in everyone's best interest to lower production to get oil prices back to levels were they are more profitable ( around 45-50 dollars a barrel). The production war between Russia and Saudi Arabia won't last

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-06-09/nigeria-vows-full-compliance-with-opec-output-cuts-by-mid-july
https://oilprice.com/Energy/Crude-Oil/Is-OPECs-No2-Finally-Complying-With-Output-Cuts.html
but, Saudis end additional cuts, so probably above 21,000
https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/commodities/views/global-economic-recovery-is-just-what-oil-markets-needed-wti-may-hit-42/articleshow/76299381.cms?from=mdr
Assuming OPEC+ will be successful in holding the line thru June based on June 6 negotiation.
Calculated to be in bin 3 but cheating or aspects of warring could have an effect.
Whatever OPEC is doing appears to be working short term. Can they keep the lid on and the price up thru all of June?

Production from January 2020 to March 2020 as reported in April has been over 27000 tb/d. February to March saw an increase of 821 tb/d This is lower than 2019 production of 29000 and 2018 production of 31000.  https://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/publications/OPEC_MOMR_Apr_2020.pdf

Based on reuters report that inMay opec was 74% compliant or abiut 24,500 tbd.  Don't look for more voluntary cuts to compensate for non-compliance. So once again the final answer will be right at the borderof two buckets or around 24k.

OPEC seems to have complied with 75% of the agreed cut in May 2020, producing 24.77 bpd on average in May - https://www.reuters.com/article/us-oil-opec-survey/opec-delivers-three-quarters-of-record-oil-cut-in-may-survey-idUSKBN23520D The main cuts seem to have come from the Saudis, UAE and Kuwait. Iraq and Nigeria have been laggards. The first set will cut further in June. And might seek greater compliance to the agreed cuts from Iraq and Nigeria.  OPEC + is looking to meet earlier (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-oil-opec-meeting/russia-has-no-objection-to-earlier-opec-meeting-sources-idUSKBN2370IS) and could suggest that the cuts be extended beyond June.  But I guess the doomsday scenarios have receded and Crude prices can be kept between USD 35 - 40. Shale producers are restarting or looking to restart. So 
Less than 18,000 tb/day  (0% from 5%) - no doomsday scenario
18,000 to 21,000 tb/day  (kept at 10%) -  still a possibility
21,000 to 24,000 tb/day  (65% from 50%) - seems to be the most possible scenario
24,000 to 27,000 tb/day  (25% from 35%) - OPEC seems to be serious about the cutbacks

Global demand is starting to pick up. OPEC will want their share, while I don't think they're ready to fully call off the price war yet, it seems unlikely that US Shale can come back quickly (given financing constraints). Still there is a lot of stockpiled oil to get through too - so it may be a while before production can pick up a lot.

Doesn't seem like people have been complying with the cuts and with oil prices increasing even more are likely not to comply. Though this is only survey data so not the most accurate.  https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/OPEC-Compliance-With-Output-Cuts-Was-Only-74-In-May.html

Based on recent reporting that offers conflicting reports of OPEC+ either extending cuts past June or evaluating the cuts and increasing production in July I will stick with a prediction similar to last week. Based on March 2020's OPEC Crude oil production based on direct communication combined with OPEC crude oil production based on secondary sources which are 26,275 tb/d and 28,612 tb/d respectively. In conjunction with the metrics above, open source information has OPEC countries cutting production for April and the following months. With that said I predict the production to be cut between 10-20% resulting in a range of 22,400 to 25,200 TB/d.

Compliance is not perfect among the OPEC states [1]. ~4.48 million bpd of the pledged reduction have been done ~74% of the agreed cuts. OPEC (without countries from OPEC+) have pumped 24.77 million barrels per day (bpd) this month. OPEC's share amounts to 6.084 million bpd. Saudi Arabia announced back in April that the cuts will be effectively ~12.5 million bpd as they plan to reduce production even more than under the OPEC agreement [2]. This means OPEC would effectively cut by ~8.8 million bpd assuming OPEC+ countries cut by ~3.6 million bpd. OPEC oil production was ~30 million bpd in April [3].  Consequently, we should see production by OPEC of ~ 21 million bpd if everyone complies. We have only four weeks left and some states have not acted fully according to the agreement. I don't expect the majority of countries to not comply, however. Thus, as of today it's likely we'll end up above 21 million bpd but below 24 million bpd. [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-oil-opec-survey/opec-delivers-three-quarters-of-record-oil-cut-in-may-survey-idUSKBN23520D
[2] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-oil-opec/opec-russia-approve-biggest-ever-oil-cut-to-support-prices-amid-coronavirus-pandemic-idUSKCN21U0J6
[3] https://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/The-Problem-With-OPECs-Production-Cut.html

OPEC carried 7mb/d stock from Q1 therefore I think it would be reasonable to include this in production planning since the goal is to not further decrease the oil prices and the way to do that is to match with the demand. The OPEC projection for demand in Q2 is around 17mb/d.
However, the agreement during the 10th OPEC non-OPEC meeting agreed on decreasing production by ~10mb/d from baseline of Oct2018 (32,9 mb/d).  Did anyone found out of the ~10 reductions were meant for just OPEC or all attendees? - my assumption is all but I know only that Russia was present as non-OPEC - but who else? Still, Russia plans to cut 2,26mb/d in June and July. If to include Russia in the ~10 reduction that leaves 8 for OPEC assuming no other countries were included.

March production was back to December/January levels. https://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/publications/OPEC_MOMR_Apr_2020.pdf And it sounds like April Production is going to be even higher.  However, production is supposed drop by 9.7m barrels over May/June: https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/OPEC-Oil-Production-Hits-13-Month-High-As-Output-Cuts-Start.html This suggests that in May production has been slashed: https://oilprice.com/Energy/Crude-Oil/OPEC-Deal-Could-Collapse-As-Oil-Prices-Shoot-Up.html This projection says the production will fall below 24m: https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/steo/report/global_oil.php Based on both the crowd forecast and the reading materials, it feels like 21-24 is the safest range.  However, it seems to make more sense to lean towards the higher ranges of the spectrum outside of that, given OPEC countries potentially cheating/demand bouncing back some.
Following @C-Paxson on this one, diluted by crowd numbers.

In conjunction with the metrics above, open source information has OPEC countries cutting production for April and the following months. With that said I predict the production to be cut between 10-20% resulting in a range of 22,400 to 25,200 TB/d.
Storages are full. Demand might see slight - tough not realistic- recovery. Therefore the cut agreed by opec+ might be a bit less.
Will not cut back too much due to states opening back up and summer months coming up.
Improvements in the world economy may lead some countries to not go through with their cuts.
If the US and EU and China start driving again, eveyone in their own vehicle, demand for fuel will climb. If demand climbs, supply will follow closely.
Weak priors on this one. Early signs that countries will adhere to promised reductions, but magnitude will be uncertain until more reporting happens.
As of 12 May OPEC and other allies have pledged to keep oil production cuts into June. Additionally, some counties have unilaterally cut production further.
likely drop, slighly hard to predict at present, numerous uncertainties

Bloomberg today "Riyadh aims to pump just under 7.5 million barrels a day in June, compared with an official target under the most recent OPEC+ agreement of just under 8.5 million a day. If Saudi Arabia makes good on its pledge, its production will drop to the lowest since mid-2002"
"Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates followed up announcing cuts of 80,000 barrels a day and 100,000 respectively."

June 2020 the impact will still be significant and maybe the second wave of Hammer will decrease impact again after a period of the Dance (release). What has been the moving average the last years... last year same time was around 29 tb/d. Production will also be shaped by the coordination which due to the shale production in USA is worse than what is has been.
if you have no market to sell the oil to, you have to cut production

Projected to be about 18,072 tb/d.   OPEC+ supply deal to reduce output by 9.7 million bpd for May and June.  (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-oil/oil-little-changed-u-s-ties-18-year-low-after-opec-cuts-demand-forecast-idUSKCN21Y042)

Committed to reducing by 9.7 m/d. for OPEC plus. OPEC share of that appears to be about 6.6 million. Producing about 30.25 m/d before agreed cut. https://www.reuters.com/article/oil-opec-survey-idUSL8N2CI8JG
Somewhere between 21-24 makes sense.
Demand is low, storage capacity is low and the price is low.
Because they have the cheapest oil and the greatest need to sell
Sebawi's insightful sources detailed below. Adjusted slightly for an anticipated increase in economic activity as lockdown eases in Western Europe.

Based on a 20% from April to May, thousands of barrels per day will hover slightly below 27,000. In June 2020 economies will likely recover slightly and production will remain at a constant pace sending price up slightly allowing companies to recover lost profits.

The majority of the major oil-consuming world has halted intra-country travel due to COVID restrictions. Oil production eclipsed oil demand in late March and April 2020. With oil storage capacity nearing its limit, and demand that continues to remain lower than normal, it will take some time (late-July or August 2020) for demand to return to a more normal level. Therefore, it will take some time for oil demand to move its way through the stored oil surplus.

The benchmark was based on production levels earlier in the year and then anticipating a mild drop. A more severe drop was ruled out due to gentle moving away from lockdown in many countries and OPEC members' traditional failure to honour the promises they make in reduction levels.
https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/opec-production-targets/

Incorporating information on OPEC+ members with the highest regular crude oil production. Russia intends to cut crude oil production by 2 mbd in May and June [1,2].
Mexico expected to cut by 100,000 bpd [3].
Kazakhstan has agreed to cut 390,000 bpd [4].
Oman will reduce crude oil production by 200,000 bpd [5, 6].
Azerbaijan intends to cut by 164,000 bpd [8]. It seems likely that the OPEC+ states will cut by  ~3.0 mbd which leaves ~9.5 mbd in cuts to the OPEC states (assuming there'll be de facto cuts of 12.5 mbd as announced by the Saudi Energy Minister [7]). If OPEC and OPEC+ comply to the cuts, I don't see how it's possible that there'll be more than 24,000 tbd or less than 18,000 tbd produced. [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/04/world/europe/russia-oil-cut.html
[2] https://oilprice.com/Energy/Crude-Oil/Russias-Oil-Output-Flat-In-March-As-OPEC-Cuts-Loom.html
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/global-oil-mexico-storage/mexico-resists-oil-output-cuts-but-scrounges-for-storage-space-as-glut-grows-idUSL2N2CA27M
[4] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-kazakhstan-oil-opec/kazakhstan-close-to-deal-with-big-oil-to-cut-output-22-sources-idUSKCN22A3FK
[5] https://www.omanobserver.om/oman-to-cut-oil-output-by-200000-bpd/
[6] https://www.spglobal.com/platts/en/market-insights/latest-news/oil/042720-oman-reveals-oil-production-cut-plans-under-opec-deal
[7] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-oil-opec/opec-russia-approve-biggest-ever-oil-cut-to-support-prices-amid-coronavirus-pandemic-idUSKCN21U0J6
[8] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-oil-azerbaijan/azerbaijan-imposes-oil-cuts-on-bp-led-fields-sources-idUSKCN225328

The current oil production by OPEC is about 24,000 tb/day. As per the April 21 news, the OPEC has agreed a deal to reduce it by 10,000 tb/day. Going by this, it will be 14,000 tb/day in May 2020. 
However, if countries begin to ease transportation, build inventories, etc, there are chances that the production could be increased by 50% from the May level, which means that the production will be 21,000 tb/day at June end. 
Hence, OPEC production forecast is between 14,000 - 21,000 tb/day at end-June 2020.

If all of OPEC were to be producing at absolute minimum volume, I'm not sure they could pull off <20,000 without capping wells. I could be wrong. I likely am, my math/understanding is quite possible misguided. All the same, this has been fascinating to dive into.

The OPEC commitment was to remove 9.7 Mb/d which coincidently is equal to Saudi Arabia's output starting in May. Cuts take time as wells and pipelines and terminals must be managed down over time.  The 9.7 Mb/d output drop would be about 34% of OPEC total Jan 2020 output. 10% - 2,832 tb/d is doable, 20% - 5,663 tb/d with pain, but 30%-8,495 tb/d seems to be more than can be accomplished short term and 35% nearly impossible. 
Jan 2020 = 28,318 tb/d --less 10%=25,486 tb/d.. less 20% = 22,654tb/d....less 30% = 19,822 . less 35% = 18,406tb/d

OPEC has stated that they intend to cut 9m b/d off production in April, which would put them somewhere between 18-19m b/d. However, their members typically agree to lower production targets and then don't cut their production by as much as they agreed to, making it likely that the total production will be less than 27m b/d but higher than the 18-19m b/d target that was announced for April-May. It seems likely that by June production will be in the 20-24m b/d range.

This one is hard. The primary difficulty comes in estimating how much of the 9.7mb/d production cut will be absorbed by OPEC (rather than OPEC+ and/or remaining oil producers). If OPEC takes 60% of that 9.7mb/d (a common estimate), then we should expect to see a 24mb/d output in June, which as we can see is strategically placed as an answer partition. Consequently, my estimate between these two partitions is relatively close. 
If this were my report, I would likely modify the ranges so as to increase my confidence level. That is, I could claim with, say, 62% certainty that tb/d for OPEC would be between 22,500 and 25,500mb/d, thereby keeping the 3mb/d increments, but increasing the confidence level.

May 2020 data shows OPEC pumped out 30-31 mb/day.  The agreed cuts (OPEC+) is looking to cut 10 mb/day. Proportionately that means a cut for OPEC in the region of 6 mb/day. OPEC is looking for a global cut in the region of 20 mb/day (wonder where that will come from though) - given the 20 - 30 % demand decrease (possibly more) expected to be seen in crude in Q2. - Total crude demand in the region of 100 mb/day
- USA largest producer (12+ mb/day)
- Total crude storage in the region of 4.5 bb
- A VLCC tanker can store 2 mb of crude This makes above 27 mb/day look pretty much out of the question     -  0%
Between 24 and 27 mb/day looks interesting                                            - 35%
Between 21 and 24 mb/day looks most likely                                            - 50%
Between 18 and 21 mb/day looks probable                                               - 10%
Less than 18 mb/day could be catastrophic and looks difficult              -   5% (but could happen in August production) - Look to make it more towards the lower ends depending on emerging information

OPEC has committed to reducing production through 2022. The CoVid shock OPEC member's economies will slow any sharp reduction in production.  There could even be a call to increase production or hold at current production levels.

OPEC will not increase production so the amount wont he ove 27000 tb/d. There is little chance production will be less than 18,000 tb/d as that would he catastrophic to OPEC nation' economies and allow the U.S. shale oil production to continue to hurt pricing.   OPEC will make a slight reduction to keep  24,000 to 27,000 tb/d to keep pressure on shale oil production while not panicking the market.
Should come in somewhere in between the extreme scenarios

Baseline forecast used time series with monthly data back to 2015 (capturing about a year before agreed declines starting late 2016). Most recent news explains OPEC countries agreed to roughly 20% cut to current production rates, so if we take that at face-value expected production for June would settle at roughly 21,000 tb/d to 22,000 tb/d. However, there is quite a bit of game theory going into this from individual countries, so my expectation is actual production cuts will not quite meet the 20% mark.

The OPEC commitment was to remove 9.7 Mb/d which coincidently is equal to Saudi Arabia's output.  Can this be achieved by countries who rely on production to meet budget goals? The 9.7 Mb/d output drop would be about 35% of OPEC total output. This question is mind boggling in implications. 10% is doable, 20% with major pain, but 30% seems to be more than can be accomplished and 35% impossible. Note to self - I have been wrong before.

Based on crowd forecasts & this article (27/4) https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/27/oil-news-crude-wti-brent-prices-today.html stating "Earlier in April, OPEC and its oil-producing allies agreed to a historic production cut that would take 9.7 million barrels per day of production offline beginning this Friday."

First of all, note the different measurements used in reporting: there is barrels per day (bpd), thousand barrels per day (tbd) and million barrels per day (mbd). OPEC reports in thousand barrels per day monthly oil market (tbd mom) [3]. Countries relevant for the forecast include  - Algeria
- Angola
- Congo
- Equatorial Guinea
- Gabon
- Iran
- Iraq
- Kuwait
- Nigeria
- Saudi Arabia
- the UAE
- Venezuela.  Other major oil producers such as the US and Russia are not included. According to Reuters, OPEC+ (including other countries such as Russia) has agreed to reduce 9.7 mbd in May and June [1]. Reuters also refers to statements by the Saudi Energy Minister that effectively ~12.5 mbd will be reduced as Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Kuwait would cut supplies steeper due to higher output in April. OPEC's share of global crude oil production amounts to ~42% [4]. OPEC+ produces more than 50% [4, 5].
If the OPEC crude oil production indeed was around the ~ 30 million barrels per day (bpd) in April [2], I don't think we'll see less than 18,000 tb/d in June. I maybe too positive in assuming that there won't be more than 27,000 tbd. [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-oil-opec/opec-russia-approve-biggest-ever-oil-cut-to-support-prices-amid-coronavirus-pandemic-idUSKCN21U0J6
[2] https://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/The-Problem-With-OPECs-Production-Cut.html
[3] https://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/publications/OPEC_MOMR_Mar_2020.pdf
[4] https://www.investopedia.com/articles/investing/081315/opec-vs-us-who-controls-oil-prices.asp
[5] https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/opec-production-targets/

Will need to consider further; although at a glance, not all outcomes appear equally probable. I'd presume Feb production levels are not in the cards, especially with the glut of crude on the market and the fact that those production levels got us into this mess to begin with.

You've got to admit that the question designers do a very good job scoping the problem and the probable solutions before we the "forecasters" see it. Therefore, follow the lead of the quesiton designer. They are smarter than we are and they understand probablility while most of us don't.

"While OPEC’s Gulf members have already begun to limit supply, it has a long way to go to reach the new target. OPEC’s share of the cut is 6.084 million bpd and based on April’s output, members need to curb supply by 6.97 million bpd."
https://www.reuters.com/article/oil-opec-survey/opec-april-oil-output-surges-to-13-month-high-before-new-cut-deal-idUSL8N2CI8JG "The survey, which tracks OPEC’s oil supply to the market and is based on sources at oil firms, OPEC, and shipping data, found that OPEC pumped a total of 30.25 million bpd of oil in April—the highest level since March 2019 and a rise of 1.61 million bpd compared to March 2020."
https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/OPEC-Oil-Production-Hits-13-Month-High-As-Output-Cuts-Start.html
